item.title: O and A: Tolstoy, Bolshoi and krakadil Gena
item.description: Oh and ah The o is the most common letter in Russian (as mentioned in Paste Sounds). Were all those o’s to have an o sound, the whole language would have changed sound. Now it has been determined that an unstressed o (usually) sounds like an a, and that was a good idea.

item.title: ш and щ: Spot the Differences
item.description: Sound For what descriptions of sounds are worth: Wikipedia compares ш to ‘sh in shop’ and ‘ch in machine,’ but when it comes to щ, it hits a dead end: ‘Dutch has no words with this sound.’ The English Wikipedia entry for shcha/щ isn’t much help either: ‘it represents the voiceless alveolo-palatal fricative /ɕ(ː)/.

item.title: Past Tense
item.description: Three Forms (or Actually Four) Masculine, feminine, and formal or plural: verbs in the past tense take on only three forms. Or actually four, but the form for оно (it) is rarely used. After all, an оно doesn’t (or didn’t) do much.
